Description: Solid-cast element for crown of large figure (possibly Osiris?) in copper alloy; pair of uraei in the shape of raised cobras wearing sun-discs, with the hoods welded and with thick links between the sun-discs and the bases; eyes, mouth and axial ridge on front of hood modelled and incised; front of hood divided by curved ribs in hollow sections which, as the hollow sun-discs, were supposed to receive coloured paste and/or glass inlays; traces of such inlays remain in the sections of the hood, whitish in centre, light green-blue on upper and lower part; loop behind each cobra’s head; lower part missing; metal quite well preserved and inlays damaged or missing.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Town (Naukratis), House of 'cache of bronzes'? (?)
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by City Art Gallery and Museum, Bristol. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

This piece could correspond to the "two snakes" element that Petrie listed in the finds from the cache of bronzes (on this cache: Petrie 1886, 41-42; Masson 2015). Two other pairs of uraei however were discovered in the same season by Petrie: Boston, Museum of Fine Arts 86.298 and Liverpool, World Museum 9,9,86,112. The identification of its context of discovery is therefore not certain. Such fittings imply the presence of a relatively large statue of an Egyptian deity (maybe Osiris?). Other fragments belonging to one or more relatively large statues with glass inlays were discovered in Naukratis (Masson forthcoming b). Fittings in the shape of uraeus (single or pair) in copper alloy found in the Delta are listed in Weiss 2012, 876-880. Very close parallel for this double-uraeus from Herakleion (Weiss 2012, 876, Pl. 69, Nr 1364). For other uraei with coloured glass inlays, see for example: Grenier 2002, 176-177, pl. XLVIII; Goddio and Fabre 2008, no. 201 (from Herakleion). Goddio, F. and Fabre D. 2008 (eds), Egypt’s sunken treasures, Munich. Grenier, J.-C. 2002, Les Bronzes du Museo Gregoriano Egizio, Vatican City. Petrie, W. M. F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I., 1884-5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Masson, A. 2015, ‘Cult and Trade. A reflexion on Egyptian metal offerings from Naukratis’, in D. Robinson and F. Goddio (eds), Thonis Heracleion in Context, Oxford Centre for Maritime Archaeology Monograph 8, Oxford, 71-88. Masson, A. forthcoming b, ‘Naukratis: Egyptian offerings in context’, in M. Bergeron and A. Masson (eds), Naukratis in Context II: Cults, Sanctuaries and Offerings. Proceedings of the Second Naukratis Project Workshop held at the British Museum, 22nd – 23rd June 2013. Weiss, K. 2012, Ägyptische Tier- und Götterbronzen aus Unterägypten : Untersuchungen zu Typus, Ikonographie und Funktion sowie der Bedeutung innerhalb der Kulturkontakte zu Griechenland, Ägypten und Altes Testament 81.
Bibliographic references: Weiss 2012 / Ägyptische Tier- und Götterbronzen aus Unterägypten : Untersuchungen zu Typus, Ikonographie und Funktion sowie der Bedeutung innerhalb der Kulturkontakte zu Griechenland (p. 877, Nr. 1369)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (MB.237) (phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: City Art Gallery and Museum, Bristol
Acquisition notes: Donated by Egypt Exploration Fund in 1886
